sentence: T he dollar's rise has been a boon to currency-hedged ETFs.
But currency movements affect more than the international exchange traded funds that diversify your portfolio.
They can impact how you allocate to domestic sectors and industries.

"Investors seeking to position their portfolios for a stronger dollar should also be considering the challenges and opportunities when investing within the U.S.," says David Mazza, head of research for State Street's SPDR ETFs .
That's becoming clear.
This earnings season,Procter & Gamble ( PG ) andGoogle ( GOOGL ) have blamed the dollar for weaker revenue.
So have3M ( MMM ) andPepsiCo ( PEP ).
The dollar's slipped lately, but Mazza believes that the long-term trend is clear: "We are 3-1/2 years into a 10-year bull run for the U.S.
dollar."
Major exporters and multinationals are more exposed to overseas markets and currency movements.
For them, a stronger dollar can be a negative.
It dents overseas profits.
For successful investing , Mazza advises investors to look for sectors and industries that depend less on foreign sales.
Think health care, financials and transportation.
SPDR S&P Healthcare Services' ( XHS ) holdings derive 23.5% of their revenues from foreign sales vs.SDPR S&P Semiconductor's (XSD) 75.4%.
"The sector's business operations are not export-driven but are reliant on domestic demand for health care services as well as intellectual property through patent development," Mazza said.
These companies benefit from a stronger dollar.
Any supplies that they import are cheaper.
And more consumers use their products and services when jobs are to be had and payrolls are fat.
The sector's profitability outlook is bright.
XHS's holdings have an estimated earnings growth rate of 14.1% over the next three to five years, according to FactSet.
For buzzy semiconductors, it's 11.9%.
Like health care services, the banking industry has a more domestic focus.SPDR S&P Bank's (KBE) holdings derive 15% of revenue from abroad.
Its 63 holdings are mostly regional banks and mortgage insurers.
They includeBank of the Ozarks (OZRK) andRadian Group (RDN).
KBE stands to gain from the dollar's gain vs. foreign currencies.
A stronger greenback makes consumers more confident.
"Those companies see increased demand for loans and mortgages," Mazza said.
KBE fell 0.8% intraday amid broad losses in the stock market today .
To benefit from the dollar rally, Mazza also advises investors to focus on sectors or industries that rely heavily on imports for operations -- specifically, energy.
Transportation stocks stand to peg bigger profits as the stronger greenback depresses gas prices.
Globally, crude oil is priced in U.S. dollars.
When the dollar is strong, oil gets cheaper at home.
For transport companies, that's a boost to the bottom line and growth, Mazza said.Delta Air Lines (DAL) andSouthwest Airlines (LUV) expect millions in savings from lower fuel prices.
SDPR S&P Transportation (XTN) has roughly 5% of its assets in both stocks combined.
The ETF's holdings derive a relatively low 25.8% of revenue from overseas sales .
XTN holdings are estimated to grow earnings 15.8% in the next few years -- more thanSPDR Biotech's (XBI) 10.2%.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
